      11h
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



Our vetting process continues to keep communities safe! During an adjustment of status interview at the Dallas field office, we identified an alien from Cameroon with an active warrant for assault. Local law enforcement swiftly took the individual into custody without incident.

      13h
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



Changing your address with the United States Postal Service will not change your address with USCIS, and USPS will not forward your mail from USCIS. Please update your information with both USCIS and USPS. Submit your change of address today: https://lnkd.in/gds4hchZ
 







      How to Change Your Address
    

      uscis.gov

      19h
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



When an alien from Mexico was seeking asylum, we discovered a record of criminal convictions: child neglect, DUI, and probation violation.

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) took her into custody at our Tampa office. This is how we are restoring the integrity of the immigration system and getting dangerous criminal aliens off our streets.

      1d
  
                      

                        Edited
                      

 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



USCIS is overhauling its Naturalization Civics Test to ensure that citizenship is reserved for aliens who fully embrace our values and principles as a nation. 
 
As a first step, USCIS is publishing the 2025 Naturalization Civics Test, which will better assess an alien’s understanding of U.S. history, government, and English language. We take our citizenship responsibilities very seriously.  
 
Learn how these changes may affect you: https://lnkd.in/eTN-PYfS

                4 Comments
            
      
 





      Like
    





      Comment
    





      Share

                172,047 followers
            


                    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

      1d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



“By ensuring only those aliens who meet all eligibility requirements, including the ability to read, write, and speak English and understand U.S. government and civics are able to naturalize, the American people can be assured that those joining us as fellow citizens are fully assimilated and will contribute to America’s greatness." - USCIS spokesman Matthew Tragesser

https://lnkd.in/eJvRkX2T
 







      EXCLUSIVE: Trump Administration Unveils Changes to US Citizenship Test
    

      https://www.dailysignal.com/

https://lnkd.in/eUWqgPj7
 







      White House unveils letter President Donald Trump will send to new US citizens
    

      foxnews.com

      2d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



We encourage all aliens in the U.S. illegally to self-deport using the CBP Home App. 
 
You’ll receive a complimentary plane ticket home, a $1,000 exit bonus upon your return home, and any unpaid fines for failing to depart previously will be forgiven.
 
 Learn more: https://lnkd.in/efrqQMsJ
 







      USCIS Supports “Project Homecoming” Self-Deportation
    

      uscis.gov
    

 

 








                    8
              


 

 





        
                1 Comment
            
      
 





      Like
    





      Comment
    





      Share
    
















 



 



              USCIS
            
 

                172,047 followers
            


                    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

      2d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



CRIMINAL HISTORY REVEALED 

An alien from Mexico came to our Tampa office for a scheduled interview, but we uncovered a staggering criminal record that spans decades.

Here’s just a portion of his criminal history: 
🔹 1988: Arrested for selling cocaine. 
🔹 1989: Convicted of cocaine possession and carrying a concealed weapon. 
🔹 1990: Convicted for selling cocaine again. 
🔹 1994: Arrested for domestic violence. 
🔹 1996: Apprehended in an operation that smuggled 14 people. 
🔹 2000: Convicted for assault. 
🔹 2001 & 2003: Convicted of DUI.
🔹 2004: Arrested and charged with assault and aggravated battery. 
🔹 2010: Convicted for driving with a suspended license.

His repeated disregard for the law and public safety is shocking. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) arrested him and he'll be deported. 
America’s communities deserve to be protected from dangerous criminal aliens.
 



 











                    25
              


 

 





        
                2 Comments
            
      
 





      Like
    





      Comment
    





      Share
    
















 



 



              USCIS
            
 

                172,047 followers
            


                    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

      2d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



Teamwork in action! At the Dallas field office, a Jordanian alien was identified for fraud and misrepresentation on an I-140 case involving being out-of-status. After a thorough review and coordination with the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the alien was apprehended without incident.

Jordan.summary:
The USCIS has recently made several announcements that may be relevant to F1 students:

1. USCIS is updating the Naturalization Civics Test to better assess an alien's understanding of U.S. history, government, and English language. This change aims to ensure that citizenship is reserved for those who fully embrace American values and principles.

2. USCIS is now allowing online filing for Form I-130 by uploading a PDF, making the process more convenient for applicants.

3. It is important for individuals to update their address with both USCIS and the United States Postal Service separately, as changing your address with USPS does not automatically update it with USCIS.

4. USCIS encourages individuals in the U.S. illegally to self-deport using the CBP Home App, offering benefits such as a complimentary plane ticket home, a $1,000 exit bonus, and forgiveness of unpaid fines for failing to depart previously.

5. USCIS continues its efforts to identify and apprehend individuals with criminal backgrounds, emphasizing the importance of protecting communities from dangerous criminal aliens.

F1 students should stay informed about these updates and ensure compliance with any relevant requirements or changes in USCIS policies.

Cameroon.summary:
The USCIS has recently made several announcements that may be relevant to F1 students:

1. USCIS is updating the Naturalization Civics Test to better assess an alien's understanding of U.S. history, government, and English language. This change aims to ensure that citizenship is reserved for those who fully embrace American values and principles.

2. USCIS is now allowing online filing for Form I-130 by uploading a PDF, making the process more convenient for applicants.

3. It is important for individuals to update their address with both USCIS and the United States Postal Service separately, as changing your address with USPS does not automatically update it with USCIS.

4. USCIS encourages individuals in the U.S. illegally to self-deport using the CBP Home App, offering benefits such as a complimentary plane ticket home, a $1,000 exit bonus, and forgiveness of unpaid fines for failing to depart previously.

5. USCIS continues its efforts to identify and apprehend individuals with criminal backgrounds, emphasizing the importance of protecting communities from dangerous criminal aliens.

F1 students should stay informed about these updates and ensure compliance with any relevant requirements or changes in USCIS policies.

      11h
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



Our vetting process continues to keep communities safe! During an adjustment of status interview at the Dallas field office, we identified an alien from Cameroon with an active warrant for assault. Local law enforcement swiftly took the individual into custody without incident.

                      Report this post
                    
    




 



Changing your address with the United States Postal Service will not change your address with USCIS, and USPS will not forward your mail from USCIS. Please update your information with both USCIS and USPS. Submit your change of address today: https://lnkd.in/gds4hchZ
 







      How to Change Your Address
    

      uscis.gov

      19h
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



When an alien from Mexico was seeking asylum, we discovered a record of criminal convictions: child neglect, DUI, and probation violation.

U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) took her into custody at our Tampa office. This is how we are restoring the integrity of the immigration system and getting dangerous criminal aliens off our streets.

                2 Comments

      1d
  
                      

                        Edited
                      

 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



USCIS is overhauling its Naturalization Civics Test to ensure that citizenship is reserved for aliens who fully embrace our values and principles as a nation. 
 
As a first step, USCIS is publishing the 2025 Naturalization Civics Test, which will better assess an alien’s understanding of U.S. history, government, and English language. We take our citizenship responsibilities very seriously.  
 
Learn how these changes may affect you: https://lnkd.in/eTN-PYfS
 



 












                    70
              


 

 





        
                4 Comments
            
      
 





      Like
    





      Comment

                172,047 followers
            


                    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

      1d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



“By ensuring only those aliens who meet all eligibility requirements, including the ability to read, write, and speak English and understand U.S. government and civics are able to naturalize, the American people can be assured that those joining us as fellow citizens are fully assimilated and will contribute to America’s greatness." - USCIS spokesman Matthew Tragesser

https://lnkd.in/eJvRkX2T
 







      EXCLUSIVE: Trump Administration Unveils Changes to US Citizenship Test
    

      https://www.dailysignal.com/

      1d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



"America has always welcomed those who embrace our values, assimilate into our society and pledge allegiance to our country. This rich heritage is now yours to protect, promote and pass down to the next generation." - President Trump in his letter to #NewUSCitizens
https://lnkd.in/eUWqgPj7
 







      White House unveils letter President Donald Trump will send to new US citizens
    

      foxnews.com

      2d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



We encourage all aliens in the U.S. illegally to self-deport using the CBP Home App. 
 
You’ll receive a complimentary plane ticket home, a $1,000 exit bonus upon your return home, and any unpaid fines for failing to depart previously will be forgiven.
 
 Learn more: https://lnkd.in/efrqQMsJ
 







      USCIS Supports “Project Homecoming” Self-Deportation
    

      uscis.gov
    

 

 








                    8
              


 

 





        
                1 Comment
            
      
 





      Like
    





      Comment
    





      Share

                172,047 followers
            


                    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    

      2d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



CRIMINAL HISTORY REVEALED 

An alien from Mexico came to our Tampa office for a scheduled interview, but we uncovered a staggering criminal record that spans decades.

Here’s just a portion of his criminal history: 
🔹 1988: Arrested for selling cocaine. 
🔹 1989: Convicted of cocaine possession and carrying a concealed weapon. 
🔹 1990: Convicted for selling cocaine again. 
🔹 1994: Arrested for domestic violence. 
🔹 1996: Apprehended in an operation that smuggled 14 people. 
🔹 2000: Convicted for assault. 
🔹 2001 & 2003: Convicted of DUI.
🔹 2004: Arrested and charged with assault and aggravated battery. 
🔹 2010: Convicted for driving with a suspended license.

His repeated disregard for the law and public safety is shocking. U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) arrested him and he'll be deported. 
America’s communities deserve to be protected from dangerous criminal aliens.

      2d
  
 
 

 












                      Report this post
                    
    




 



Teamwork in action! At the Dallas field office, a Jordanian alien was identified for fraud and misrepresentation on an I-140 case involving being out-of-status. After a thorough review and coordination with the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the alien was apprehended without incident.

1. USCIS is updating the Naturalization Civics Test to better assess an alien's understanding of U.S. history, government, and English language. This change aims to ensure that citizenship is reserved for those who fully embrace American values and principles.

2. USCIS is now allowing online filing for Form I-130 by uploading a PDF, making the process more convenient for applicants.

3. It is important for individuals to update their address with both USCIS and the United States Postal Service separately, as changing your address with USPS does not automatically update it with USCIS.

4. USCIS encourages individuals in the U.S. illegally to self-deport using the CBP Home App, offering benefits such as a complimentary plane ticket home, a $1,000 exit bonus, and forgiveness of unpaid fines for failing to depart previously.

5. USCIS continues its efforts to identify and apprehend individuals with criminal backgrounds, emphasizing the importance of protecting communities from dangerous criminal aliens.

F1 students should stay informed about these updates and ensure compliance with any relevant requirements or changes in USCIS policies.
